Ovo skromno kašnjenje je mala cijena za ustavnu usklađenost i očuvanje sudske nezavisnosti.

assessments.summary_mne: Jednoglasno vraćanje neradnih nedjelja za trgovinske radnike od strane Skupštine, doneseno direktno i neposredno kao odgovor na odluku Ustavnog suda koja je poništila istu odredbu, pokreće ozbiljna pitanja vladavine prava i nezavisnosti sudstva. Iako je cilj socijalne politike zaštite odmora radnika legitiman i utemeljen na standardima ljudskih prava, način i brzina ovog zakonodavnog odgovora — vanredna sjednica sazivana posebno da bi se prevazišlo obrazloženje Suda bez smislenog rješavanja identificiranih ustavnih nedostataka — potkopava autoritet Ustavnog suda i prijeti da stvori opasan precedent za zaobilaženje sudskog nadzora od strane izvršne i zakonodavne vlasti u Crnoj Gori.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ova odluka, iako socijalno dobronamjerna, predstavlja zabrinjavajući izazov autoritetu Ustavnog suda i vladavini prava. Skupština je zapravo poništila ustavnu odluku bez dokazivih ispravki pravnih nedostataka koje je Sud identificirao. Ministarstvo pravde preporučuje da svaki ponovo doneseni zakon o zatvaranju nedjeljom mora suštinski riješiti pitanja jednakog tretmana i preduzetničke slobode koje je istakao Sud, i treba da bude praćen pravilnom procjenom regulatornog uticaja i adekvatnim vacatio legis periodom.
key_concerns_mne: Direktno zakonodavno poništavanje odluke Ustavnog suda bez dokazivog rješavanja identificiranih ustavnih nedostataka (jednakog tretmana, preduzetničke slobode), što potkopava obavezujuću prirodu ustavnog sudovanja

Ozbiljna prijetnja nezavisnosti sudstva i autoritetu Ustavnog suda — kritičnog mjerila EU Poglavlja 23 — prenošenjem poruke da će zakonodavac jednostavno ponovo donijeti poništene odredbe putem vanrednih sjednica
Neposredno stupanje na snagu bez adekvatnog vacatio legis-a krši princip pravne sigurnosti i uskraćuje pogođenim preduzećima razuman rok za prilagođavanje poslovanja
Odsustvo procjene regulatornog uticaja i smislenih javnih konsultacija, zaobilaženje standarda transparentnosti i dobrog upravljanja koje zahtijevaju kriterijumi za pristupanje EU
Velika vjerovatnoća da će vraćena odredba biti izložena novom ustavnom osporavanju, što potencijalno stvara pravnu nesigurnost i suprotstavljeni ciklus između Skupštine i Ustavnog suda

Zabrinutost zbog diskriminatorne primjene koju je istakao Ustavni sud — dozvoljavajući nekim preduzećima da rade nedjeljom dok se drugima zabranjuje — može ostati prisutna u izmijenjenom zakonu ako izuzeci ostanu selektivni
Negativan signal Evropskoj komisiji u vezi sa političkom kulturom Crne Gore poštovanja sudskog nadzora, koji će vjerovatno biti istaknuto u sljedećem Izvještaju EU o napretku
recommendations_mne: Sprovesti hitnu pravnu provjeru usvojenih amandmana kako bi se verificiralo da li su specifični ustavni nedostaci identificirani od strane Ustavnog suda (diskriminatorni izuzeci, nesrazmjerno ograničenje preduzetničke slobode) suštinski riješeni u novom tekstu

Ako amandmani ne otklanjaju ustavne nedostatke, pripremiti dopunski zakonodavni prijedlog sa pravilno formulisanim režimom zatvaranja nedjeljom koji primjenjuje jedinstvena pravila na uporedive poslovne kategorije, sa proporcionalnim i nediskriminatornim izuzecima

Uvesti adekvatan vacatio legis period (minimum 30 dana) prije sprovođenja kako bi se poštovala pravna sigurnost i omogućilo preduzećima da se prilagode, potencijalno kroz vladinu uredbu koja odlaže primjenu
Naručiti cjelovitu procjenu regulatornog uticaja koja ispituje ekonomske efekte na trgovinske radnike, preduzeća, turizam i potrošače, i objaviti je za javne konsultacije
Angažirati Venecijansku komisiju za mišljenje o usklađenosti ove zakonodavne prakse sa evropskim standardima o ustavnom sudovanju i nezavisnosti sudstva

Uspostaviti formalni protokol u okviru Skupštine za odgovaranje na odluke Ustavnog suda koji zahtijeva pravnu analizu koja pokazuje kako predloženi amandmani rješavaju specifične osnove Suda za poništavanje prije bilo kakvog glasanja

Razmotriti uključivanje odredbe o fleksibilnosti tokom turističke sezone (ograničen rad nedjeljom tokom vršnih turističkih mjeseci) u konačni zakon kako bi se pokazala proporcionalnost i odgovor na legitimne konkurentne interese
Pripremiti proaktivnu komunikaciju upućenu Evropskoj komisiji koja objašnjava obrazloženje vlade i pokazuje da je vladavina prava poštovana u zakonodavnom procesu

assessments.summary: While the protection of workers' rights is a legitimate policy objective consistent with EU social policy values, the manner in which Parliament reinstated the Sunday trading ban — through an extraordinary session designed to override a Constitutional Court ruling — raises serious rule-of-law concerns that directly undermine Montenegro's EU accession prospects. The unanimous, rapid legislative response to circumvent a judicial finding of unconstitutionality sends a troubling signal to Brussels at a time when Montenegro's credibility on judicial independence and constitutional order is under intense scrutiny in Chapters 23 and 24.
assessments.executive_summary: Parliament's rush to override the Constitutional Court's ruling on Sunday trading, regardless of the policy's social merits, creates a significant rule-of-law problem for Montenegro's EU accession process. The European Commission will likely flag this as interference with judicial independence under Chapters 23 and 24. The Ministry recommends that any future legislative action on Sunday trading be preceded by proper constitutional review and structured in a manner that respects the Court's reasoning on proportionality and non-discrimination.
assessments.reasoning:
The substance of the decision — guaranteeing retail workers a weekly rest day — is broadly compatible with EU labour standards. The EU Working Time Directive (2003/88/EC) mandates a minimum 24-hour uninterrupted rest period per seven-day period, and many EU member states have Sunday trading restrictions of varying scope (Germany's Ladenschlussgesetz, Austria's Öffnungszeitengesetz, Poland's progressive Sunday ban). The policy goal itself is therefore not inherently problematic from an acquis alignment standpoint.

However, the process by which this decision was taken is deeply concerning from an EU integration perspective and risks significant damage to Montenegro's accession trajectory.

First, and most critically, the Constitutional Court ruled that the original Sunday closure provision violated constitutional principles of entrepreneurial freedom and equal treatment — specifically because the law discriminated between business types, allowing some to operate on Sundays while prohibiting others. Parliament's immediate response was to convene an extraordinary session and reinstate essentially the same prohibition. This raises the fundamental question of whether the new provision adequately addresses the Court's constitutional objections regarding proportionality and non-discrimination. If the amendments merely re-enact the struck-down provision without curing the constitutional defects identified by the Court, this amounts to legislative defiance of judicial review — one of the most serious rule-of-law red flags the European Commission monitors.

This concern goes to the heart of Chapters 23 (Judiciary and Fundamental Rights) and 24 (Justice, Freedom and Security), which are the most politically sensitive chapters in Montenegro's accession negotiations and have been identified as those where the most progress is needed. The European Commission's annual progress reports have repeatedly emphasized the importance of judicial independence and the proper functioning of constitutional review mechanisms. A pattern of legislative override of Constitutional Court rulings would almost certainly be flagged in the next Country Report and could contribute to a slowdown or stalling of progress on interim benchmarks for Chapters 23 and 24.

Second, the unanimity of the vote (62-0) and the speed of the extraordinary session suggest a politically driven process rather than one guided by careful legal analysis of how to achieve the legitimate social policy goal while respecting constitutional constraints. The European Commission values inclusive, evidence-based legislative processes with proper impact assessments and stakeholder consultations — requirements that are difficult to meet in an extraordinary session convened in direct reaction to a court ruling.

Third, the economic arguments advanced during the debate — particularly the claim that Sunday trading leads to price increases and inflation — are not supported by mainstream economic evidence and suggest the debate was driven more by political positioning than rigorous policy analysis. This is relevant because Chapter 8 (Competition Policy) and Chapter 20 (Enterprise and Industrial Policy) both require Montenegro to demonstrate commitment to market-oriented economic governance.

Fourth, regarding Chapter 19 (Social Policy and Employment), while the EU acquis does support workers' rights to rest, the specific modality of a blanket Sunday ban is a member state competence issue. The EU does not mandate Sunday closures — it mandates adequate weekly rest. Montenegro could achieve the same social protection objective through means that do not raise the constitutional problems the Court identified, for instance by ensuring all retail workers receive a guaranteed weekly rest day without specifying Sunday universally, or by crafting a more proportionate regime with proper exemptions.

On the positive side, the decision does reflect a societal commitment to work-life balance and gender equality considerations (as raised by Deputy Andrić regarding women's double burden), which align with EU values under the European Pillar of Social Rights. The mention of a possible modified version allowing limited Sunday operations during peak tourist season suggests some awareness of the need for proportionality.

From a regional cooperation perspective, this decision is relatively neutral. Croatia, as a neighbouring EU member, allows Sunday trading with some restrictions, while Serbia has no blanket ban. The decision does not materially affect Montenegro's standing in the Berlin Process or Western Balkans cooperation frameworks.

IPA funding implications are indirect but real: if the European Commission perceives a deterioration in rule-of-law standards, this could affect the overall political assessment that underpins IPA III funding decisions and the pace of accession support programming.
key_concerns: Legislative override of the Constitutional Court ruling raises serious judicial independence and rule-of-law concerns directly relevant to Chapters 23 and 24 benchmarks
The extraordinary session format likely precluded proper regulatory impact assessment, stakeholder consultation, and legal scrutiny — all expected under EU better regulation standards

The new amendments may replicate the same constitutional defects (discrimination between business types, disproportionate restriction on entrepreneurial freedom) that the Court struck down, risking another cycle of invalidation
The European Commission's next Country Report on Montenegro will almost certainly reference this episode as a potential rule-of-law concern
The unanimity and speed of the response create an appearance of Parliament subordinating constitutional review to political consensus, which undermines the separation of powers
Economic arguments made during debate (Sunday trading causing inflation) lack empirical basis and may raise concerns about evidence-based policymaking under Chapters 8 and 20

The blanket nature of the ban, without addressing the Court's proportionality concerns, may conflict with EU internal market principles relevant to Chapter 1 (Free Movement of Goods) and the Services Directive framework
recommendations: Immediately commission a thorough legal analysis of whether the adopted amendments adequately address the specific constitutional defects identified by the Constitutional Court, and if not, proactively prepare corrective legislation before the Court is petitioned again

Prepare a detailed explanatory memorandum for the European Commission's desk officers, proactively explaining Montenegro's reasoning and demonstrating that the legislative action respects the Court's institutional role

Conduct a retrospective Regulatory Impact Assessment (RIA) for the amendments, consistent with EU better regulation practices, including economic impact modelling, stakeholder consultation records, and proportionality analysis
Develop the tourist-season exemption provision urgently and frame it as evidence that Montenegro is committed to proportionate regulation rather than blanket prohibitions

Engage with the European Commission's DG NEAR early to frame this decision within the context of EU social policy values (European Pillar of Social Rights) rather than allowing it to be perceived solely as a rule-of-law concern

In future legislative responses to Constitutional Court rulings, ensure a minimum consultation period and avoid extraordinary sessions unless genuinely urgent, to demonstrate respect for due process and judicial review

Brief Montenegro's Chief Negotiator and the negotiating teams for Chapters 23, 24, and 19 on the decision and prepare talking points that emphasize the social protection rationale while acknowledging the procedural concerns

counter_proposal.title: Proportionate Weekly Rest Guarantee with Constitutional Safeguards
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than reinstating a blanket Sunday trading ban through an extraordinary session that risks being seen as overriding the Constitutional Court, the Ministry of EU Integration would have recommended a measured legislative process: first, a formal Government analysis of the Court's ruling to identify the precise constitutional defects; second, drafting of a new provision that guarantees all retail workers a minimum weekly rest day (not necessarily Sunday for all) while establishing a proportionate, non-discriminatory exemption framework; and third, adoption through regular parliamentary procedure with full RIA and stakeholder consultation. This approach achieves the same social protection goal while respecting constitutional review and demonstrating EU-compatible legislative practice.
key_changes: Replace the blanket Sunday ban with a guaranteed 'weekly rest day' right for all retail workers, with Sunday as the default but with a structured framework for employer-employee agreements on alternative rest days where operationally justified

Address the Constitutional Court's non-discrimination concern by creating a uniform, transparent exemption regime applicable to all business types based on objective criteria (essential services, tourism zones, seasonal needs) rather than arbitrary business-type distinctions
Include a mandatory Regulatory Impact Assessment and 30-day public consultation period before adoption, demonstrating commitment to EU better regulation standards
Adopt through regular parliamentary procedure rather than an extraordinary session, to avoid the appearance of legislative urgency aimed at circumventing judicial review
Include a built-in review clause requiring Parliament to assess the law's impact after 12 months, with input from social partners, the Constitutional Court's reasoning, and EU Commission feedback
expected_benefits: Achieves the same worker protection objective without creating a rule-of-law vulnerability in Chapters 23 and 24
Demonstrates to the European Commission that Montenegro respects judicial review and pursues evidence-based, proportionate regulation
Reduces the risk of a second Constitutional Court challenge and the institutional damage of repeated legislative-judicial confrontation

Provides flexibility for the tourism sector and economic operators while maintaining strong worker protections, aligning with both Chapter 19 (Social Policy) and Chapter 20 (Enterprise and Industrial Policy)
Establishes a positive precedent for how Montenegro handles judicial review of legislation — a key indicator of rule-of-law maturity that Brussels monitors closely
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility but requiring 2-3 months for proper drafting and consultation rather than the single-day extraordinary session approach. The political will clearly exists given the unanimous vote, and a more carefully crafted approach would likely still command broad parliamentary support. The main obstacle is the political desire for immediate action, but the Ministry would argue that a short delay is far preferable to the reputational and accession-process costs of appearing to override the Constitutional Court. An interim administrative instruction could provide transitional worker protections during the drafting period.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Proporcionalna garancija sedmičnog odmora sa ustavnim zaštitama
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto ponovnog uvođenja opšte zabrane trgovine nedjeljom putem vanredne sjednice koja rizikuje da bude viđena kao zaobilaženje Ustavnog suda, Ministarstvo za evropske integracije bi preporučilo odmjeren zakonodavni proces: prvo, formalna analiza Vlade o odluci Suda kako bi se identifikovali precizni ustavni nedostaci; drugo, izrada nove odredbe koja garantuje svim radnicima u maloprodaji minimalan sedmični dan odmora (ne nužno nedjelja za sve) uz uspostavljanje proporcionalnog, nediskriminatornog okvira za izuzetke; i treće, usvajanje kroz redovnu parlamentarnu proceduru sa potpunom procjenom uticaja regulative i konsultacijama sa zainteresovanim stranama. Ovaj pristup postiže isti cilj socijalne zaštite uz poštovanje ustavnog preispitivanja i demonstrira zakonodavnu praksu kompatibilnu sa EU.
key_changes_mne: Zamijeniti opštu zabranu trgovine nedjeljom garantovanim pravom na 'sedmični dan odmora' za sve radnike u maloprodaji, sa nedjeljom kao podrazumijevanim danom ali sa strukturiranim okvirom za sporazume između poslodavca i zaposlenog o alternativnim danima odmora gdje je to operativno opravdano

Odgovoriti na zabrinutost Ustavnog suda zbog diskriminacije kreiranjem uniformnog, transparentnog režima izuzetaka koji se primjenjuje na sve vrste poslovanja na osnovu objektivnih kriterijuma (osnovne usluge, turističke zone, sezonske potrebe) umjesto proizvoljnih razlika po vrsti poslovanja
Uključiti obaveznu procjenu uticaja regulative i 30-dnevni period javne konsultacije prije usvajanja, demonstrirajući posvećenost EU standardima bolje regulative
Usvojiti kroz redovnu parlamentarnu proceduru umjesto vanredne sjednice, kako bi se izbjegao utisak zakonodavne hitnosti usmjerene na zaobilaženje sudskog preispitivanja

Uključiti ugrađenu klauzulu o reviziji koja zahtijeva od Parlamenta da procijeni uticaj zakona nakon 12 mjeseci, sa inputom socijalnih partnera, obrazloženja Ustavnog suda i povratnih informacija Evropske komisije
expected_benefits_mne: Postiže isti cilj zaštite radnika bez kreiranja ranjivosti vladavine prava u poglavljima 23 i 24
Demonstrira Evropskoj komisiji da Crna Gora poštuje sudsko preispitivanje i slijedi regulativu zasnovanu na dokazima i proporcionalnost
Smanjuje rizik od drugog ustavnog osporavanja i institucionalne štete od ponovljenih sukoba između zakonodavne i sudske vlasti

Pruža fleksibilnost za turistički sektor i privredne subjekte uz održavanje jake zaštite radnika, usklađujući se i sa poglavljem 19 (Socijalna politika) i poglavljem 20 (Preduzetništvo i industrijska politika)
Uspostavlja pozitivan presedan za način na koji Crna Gora postupa sa sudskim preispitivanjem zakonodavstva — ključni indikator zrelosti vladavine prava koji Brisel pažljivo prati
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost ali zahtijeva 2-3 mjeseca za pravilnu izradu i konsultacije umjesto pristupa vanredne jednodnevne sjednice. Politička volja jasno postoji s obzirom na jednoglasno glasanje, i pažljivije osmišljen pristup bi vjerovatno i dalje imao široku parlamentarnu podršku. Glavna prepreka je politička želja za trenutnom akcijom, ali Ministarstvo bi argumentovalo da je kratko kašnjenje daleko poželjnije od reputacionih troškova i troškova po proces pristupanja koji proizilaze iz utiska zaobilaženja Ustavnog suda. Privremena administrativna instrukcija bi mogla pružiti prelaznu zaštitu radnika tokom perioda izrade.

assessments.summary_mne: Iako je zaštita prava radnika legitiman cilj politike u skladu sa vrijednostima socijalne politike EU, način na koji je Skupština ponovo uvela zabranu trgovine nedjeljom — putem vanredne sjednice osmišljene da poništi odluku Ustavnog suda — postavlja ozbiljna pitanja u pogledu vladavine prava koja direktno ugrožavaju izglede Crne Gore za pristupanje EU. Jednoglasan i brz zakonodavni odgovor s ciljem zaobilaženja sudskog utvrđivanja neustavnosti šalje zabrinjavajući signal Briselu u vrijeme kada su kredibilitet Crne Gore u pogledu nezavisnosti pravosuđa i ustavnog poretka pod intenzivnom kontrolom u Poglavljima 23 i 24.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Žurba Skupštine da poništi odluku Ustavnog suda o trgovini nedjeljom, bez obzira na socijalne vrijednosti politike, stvara značajan problem vladavine prava za proces pristupanja Crne Gore EU. Evropska komisija će vjerovatno označiti ovo kao miješanje u nezavisnost pravosuđa u okviru Poglavlja 23 i 24. Ministarstvo preporučuje da bilo koja buduća zakonodavna akcija u vezi trgovine nedjeljom bude prethodena pravilnom ustavnom kontrolom i strukturirana na način koji poštuje obrazloženje Suda o proporcionalnosti i nediskriminaciji.
key_concerns_mne: Zakonodavno poništavanje odluke Ustavnog suda postavlja ozbiljna pitanja nezavisnosti pravosuđa i vladavine prava direktno relevantna za mjerila Poglavlja 23 i 24

Format vanredne sjednice vjerovatno je onemogućio pravilnu procjenu regulatornog uticaja, konsultacije sa zainteresovanim stranama i pravnu kontrolu — sve što se očekuje prema standardima bolje regulacije EU
Nove izmjene mogu replicirati iste ustavne nedostatke (diskriminacija između vrsta preduzeća, nesrazmjerno ograničenje preduzetničke slobode) koje je Sud ukinuo, riskirajući novi ciklus poništavanja
Sljedeći Izvještaj Evropske komisije o napretku Crne Gore gotovo sigurno će referisati ovaj slučaj kao potencijalnu zabrinutost u pogledu vladavine prava
Jednoglasnost i brzina odgovora stvaraju privid da Skupština podređuje ustavnu kontrolu političkom konsenzusu, što potkopava podjelu vlasti

Ekonomski argumenti iznijeti tokom rasprave (trgovina nedjeljom uzrokuje inflaciju) nemaju empirijsku osnovu i mogu izazvati zabrinutost u pogledu donošenja politika zasnovanih na dokazima u okviru Poglavlja 8 i 20

Opšta priroda zabrane, bez rješavanja pitanja proporcionalnosti koje je Sud pokrenuo, može biti u sukobu sa principima unutrašnjeg tržišta EU relevantnim za Poglavlje 1 (Slobodno kretanje robe) i okvir Direktive o uslugama

Pripremiti detaljan obrazložni memorandum za službenike Evropske komisije, proaktivno objašnjavajući obrazloženje Crne Gore i demonstrirajući da zakonodavna akcija poštuje institucionalnu ulogu Suda

Sprovesti retrospektivnu Procjenu regulatornog uticaja (RIA) za izmjene, u skladu sa praksama bolje regulacije EU, uključujući modeliranje ekonomskog uticaja, zapise konsultacija sa zainteresovanim stranama i analizu proporcionalnosti
Hitno razviti odredbu o izuzetku za turističku sezonu i predstaviti je kao dokaz da je Crna Gora posvećena proporcionalnoj regulaciji umjesto generalnih zabrana

U budućim zakonodavnim odgovorima na odluke Ustavnog suda, osigurati minimalan period konsultacija i izbjegavati vanredne sjednice osim ako nije stvarno hitno, kako bi se demonstriralo poštovanje propisane procedure i sudske kontrole

assessments.summary: While the Ministry of Economy recognizes the legitimate social policy objectives behind reinstating non-working Sundays for retail workers, the manner in which this decision was adopted — through an extraordinary parliamentary session to override a Constitutional Court ruling, with unanimous support but minimal economic impact analysis — raises serious concerns about legal certainty, investor confidence, the competitiveness of Montenegro's retail and tourism sectors, and the broader signal sent to the business community and EU accession partners regarding rule of law and separation of powers.
assessments.executive_summary: The reinstatement of non-working Sundays for retail workers, while socially motivated, represents a negative economic signal due to its circumvention of a Constitutional Court ruling, lack of economic impact assessment, and disproportionate burden on SMEs and the tourism sector. The Ministry recommends a flexible, seasonal framework that balances workers' rights with economic competitiveness.
assessments.reasoning:
The Ministry of Economy approaches this decision from multiple angles and finds that, despite its social merit, the economic consequences and institutional risks outweigh the stated benefits.

**Legal Certainty and Investor Confidence:** The most concerning aspect of this decision is the institutional dynamic it reveals. The Constitutional Court struck down Article 35a on grounds of violating entrepreneurial freedom and equal treatment — both foundational principles of market economies and core requirements under EU accession Chapter 3 (Right of Establishment and Freedom to Provide Services) and Chapter 8 (Competition Policy). Parliament's immediate response — convening an extraordinary session to re-legislate essentially the same restriction — sends a troubling signal to domestic and foreign investors. It suggests that judicial review can be swiftly overridden by parliamentary supermajorities, undermining the separation of powers. Foreign investors, particularly those in retail, franchising, and tourism-adjacent services, monitor such developments closely. Montenegro's FDI stock, already concentrated in real estate and energy, needs diversification into services and retail — exactly the sectors most affected by this law.

**Impact on GDP and Retail Turnover:** Montenegro's retail trade sector contributes approximately 10-12% of GDP. Sunday is a significant trading day, particularly in coastal municipalities during the tourism season (May–October) and in Podgorica's growing consumer market year-round. European evidence is mixed: Croatia's experience with Sunday closures (introduced in 2009, repealed in 2019, partially reinstated) showed measurable declines in retail turnover, estimated at 3-5% in affected segments. For Montenegro, with a GDP of approximately €6.3 billion, even a modest 1-2% reduction in retail sector output translates to tens of millions of euros in lost economic activity annually. The claim by Deputy Pižurica that Sunday closures prevent inflation is economically unfounded — restricting supply and competition hours is more likely to increase consumer prices, not reduce them.

**SME and Entrepreneurship Impact:** Montenegro has approximately 30,000 active enterprises, the vast majority of which are micro and small businesses. Many family-owned retail operations, convenience stores, and small shops rely on Sunday trading for a disproportionate share of their weekly revenue. Unlike large retail chains that can absorb the revenue loss across six trading days, SMEs face a direct hit to their bottom line. The law, as described, does not appear to differentiate between large retailers and micro-enterprises, which is precisely the equal treatment concern the Constitutional Court identified. This one-size-fits-all approach penalizes the most vulnerable segment of the business ecosystem.

**Tourism Competitiveness:** Montenegro's tourism sector accounts for over 20% of GDP (directly and indirectly). The country competes directly with Croatia, Albania, and Greece for coastal tourism. Visitors from Western Europe, the Gulf states, and increasingly East Asia expect seven-day retail availability. While proponents argue that tourism problems cannot be attributed to Sunday closures, this ignores the competitive reality: tourists spend on retail, dining, and services throughout the week, and Montenegro's coastal municipalities (Budva, Kotor, Tivat, Herceg Novi) derive significant revenue from Sunday retail activity. The mention of a 'modified version allowing limited Sunday operations during peak tourist seasons' is encouraging but remains merely 'under consideration' — it should have been part of the adopted legislation.

**Labor Market Considerations:** The Ministry acknowledges that retail workers, particularly women, face challenging working conditions, and the arguments about double shifts and dignity carry weight. However, the appropriate policy response is not a blanket ban on Sunday trading but rather strengthened labor protections: mandatory premium pay for Sunday work (150-200% of regular wages, as practiced in Germany and Austria), guaranteed minimum rest periods in line with the EU Working Time Directive, voluntary opt-in mechanisms for workers, and robust Labor Inspectorate enforcement. Montenegro's informal economy, estimated at 25-35% of GDP, means that a significant portion of retail workers lack formal protections regardless of what the law says about Sundays. The enforcement gap is the real problem.

**EU Accession Implications:** Montenegro's EU accession process requires alignment with the EU Services Directive (2006/123/EC), which promotes the freedom to provide services and limits unjustified restrictions on commercial activity. While EU member states retain discretion on Sunday trading rules (Germany, Austria, and parts of Belgium maintain restrictions), these are typically accompanied by granular exceptions, regional flexibility, and robust compensatory labor protections. The blanket nature of Montenegro's reinstated provision, combined with the manner of its adoption overriding a constitutional court, may attract scrutiny in the EU's annual progress report under the rule of law and economic criteria chapters.

assessments.summary: The reinstatement of non-working Sundays for retail workers is a moderately positive decision from an education perspective. While not directly targeting education policy, it has meaningful indirect benefits for student welfare, family cohesion, and the working conditions of students and parents employed in retail—many of whom are VET graduates, part-time university students, or parents of school-age children. The decision supports social equity goals aligned with EU standards, though it misses an opportunity to explicitly connect labor protections with educational participation and lifelong learning.
assessments.executive_summary: This labor law amendment carries indirect but genuinely positive implications for education: it protects family time essential for parental involvement in children's schooling, shields part-time student-workers from exploitative scheduling, and signals a social protection orientation that can help mitigate brain drain. The Ministry of Education recommends the government pair this measure with targeted policies linking guaranteed rest days to educational participation and lifelong learning opportunities.
assessments.reasoning:
The reinstatement of Sunday as a non-working day for retail employees touches the education domain through several indirect but significant channels.

First, regarding student welfare and equity: a substantial number of Montenegro's approximately 20,000 university students and upper-secondary VET students work part-time in retail to fund their education. The retail sector is one of the largest employers of young people, particularly in coastal municipalities (Budva, Kotor, Bar) and Podgorica's growing commercial centers. Without Sunday protections, these students face schedule compression that undermines their ability to attend lectures, prepare for exams, and participate in practical training. The unanimous reinstatement of Sunday rest helps preserve minimum conditions for educational participation among working students. This is particularly relevant given that Montenegro's higher education completion rates remain below the EU average, and any additional scheduling burden on student-workers risks increasing dropout.

Second, concerning basic and secondary education quality: parental involvement is one of the strongest predictors of student achievement, as consistently shown in PISA assessments—where Montenegro has historically scored below OECD averages (approximately 410–420 across domains in recent cycles). Many parents of primary and secondary school children work in retail. A guaranteed common rest day enables family engagement in children's homework, extracurricular activities, and school events. The argument raised by Deputy Andrić about women's double burden is particularly pertinent: mothers in Montenegro disproportionately bear both employment and domestic/caregiving responsibilities. Removing their one guaranteed day off would directly erode the time available for educational support of children, deepening equity gaps between families with and without retail-employed parents.

Third, on VET and workforce considerations: Montenegro's vocational education system feeds directly into the retail and services sector. The Law on Vocational Education and Training, aligned with the Copenhagen process and EU VET frameworks, emphasizes dual education models that require coordination between schools and employers. Sunday closures provide a stable scheduling framework that makes it easier for VET students in dual programs to balance workplace learning with classroom instruction. Furthermore, if retail workers—many of them VET graduates—are afforded better working conditions, this improves the perceived dignity and attractiveness of VET pathways, a persistent challenge across the Western Balkans.

Fourth, regarding brain drain mitigation: one of the most critical education-adjacent challenges for Montenegro is the emigration of young, educated citizens. While a single labor protection measure will not reverse brain drain, it contributes to a broader quality-of-life signal. Young Montenegrins comparing working conditions at home with those in EU member states (where Sunday trading restrictions are common in Germany, Austria, and parts of France) may view this protection positively. The decision aligns Montenegro's labor standards more closely with those of several EU member states, which is relevant as the country progresses through EU accession negotiations under Cluster 2 (Internal Market) and Cluster 3 (Competitiveness and Inclusive Growth).

Fifth, on EU education standards alignment: while this is a labor law rather than an education law, the EU's European Pillar of Social Rights (Principle 10 on healthy, safe, and well-adapted work environment, and Principle 9 on work-life balance) underpins the logic of this decision. The European Commission's country reports on Montenegro have repeatedly noted the need for stronger social protections. From an education perspective, aligning with these social standards creates a more supportive ecosystem for learners of all ages.

However, the decision has limitations from an education standpoint. It does not explicitly address or leverage the freed Sunday time for educational purposes. It also creates potential tension in tourism-heavy municipalities where seasonal educational programming (summer schools, language camps, cultural education) might benefit from a more flexible framework. The mention that a modified version allowing limited Sunday operations during peak tourist season remains under consideration is relevant here—coastal VET programs in hospitality and tourism may need nuanced treatment.

The unanimous passage (62-0) and the extraordinary session procedure suggest strong political consensus, which is welcome, but the speed of adoption raises a procedural concern: there appears to have been no formal consultation with the Ministry of Education or institutions representing students and young workers, which is a missed opportunity.

assessments.summary: While the Ministry of Tourism recognises the legitimate social protection objectives behind reinstating non-working Sundays for retail workers, the blanket application of this measure without a robust seasonal exemption framework poses material risks to Montenegro's tourism competitiveness, visitor satisfaction, and revenue generation — particularly during the critical May–October season when tourism accounts for approximately 40% of GDP. The unanimous parliamentary vote reflects genuine worker welfare concerns, but the decision was taken without adequate consultation with tourism stakeholders and without embedding the seasonal flexibility that Montenegro's tourism-dependent economy requires.
assessments.executive_summary: The reinstatement of non-working Sundays, while socially motivated, risks damaging Montenegro's tourism competitiveness during peak season when visitors expect full retail and service availability. The Ministry's top concern is the absence of a binding seasonal exemption for tourist zones, and the key recommendation is to fast-track the reportedly 'under consideration' seasonal modification before the 2026 summer season begins.
assessments.reasoning:
Montenegro's tourism sector is overwhelmingly concentrated in the May–October window, with Sundays representing roughly 14% of all available shopping and commercial engagement days during that critical period. International visitors — particularly cruise passengers arriving in Kotor Bay (over 500,000 annually), package tourists in Budva and Herceg Novi, and increasingly affluent visitors to Porto Montenegro in Tivat — have strong expectations of Sunday retail availability. This is not merely a matter of convenience; retail spending by tourists constitutes a significant share of per-visitor revenue, encompassing souvenirs, local produce, fashion, and duty-related purchases.

The decision's timing is particularly concerning. February publication in the Official Gazette means the law will be in full force well before the 2026 tourist season begins, with no guarantee that the 'modified version allowing limited Sunday operations during peak tourist seasons' referenced in parliamentary debate will be enacted in time. The Ministry notes that this seasonal exemption remains merely 'under consideration' — not scheduled, not drafted, and not guaranteed. This creates immediate regulatory uncertainty for tourism operators, municipal tourism boards, and foreign tour operators who programme Montenegro as a destination months in advance.

From a competitive standpoint, Montenegro's key regional rivals — Croatia, Albania, and Greece — all permit Sunday retail operations in tourist areas during summer. Croatia, an EU member, maintains specific exemptions for municipalities classified as tourist zones, allowing shops under 200 square metres to operate freely and larger stores to open on designated Sundays during peak season. Albania has no Sunday closure restrictions. Greece permits Sunday openings in designated tourist areas from April to October. A blanket Sunday closure in Montenegro, even temporarily, sends a signal of reduced visitor-friendliness at precisely the moment when Montenegro is trying to position itself as a premium Mediterranean destination and advance its EU accession process.

The cruise ship dimension warrants special attention. Kotor, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, receives cruise ships on all days of the week, including Sundays. When thousands of cruise passengers disembark for 6–10 hour port calls and find the Old Town's retail establishments shuttered, the reputational damage is immediate and amplified through social media and cruise line reviews. Cruise lines actively re-route itineraries away from ports perceived as 'closed' or offering poor visitor experience, and competing ports like Dubrovnik, Split, and Corfu are eager to absorb redirected traffic.

The parliamentary debate acknowledged tourism concerns but dismissed them summarily, with proponents arguing that 'tourism problems could not be attributed to Sunday closures.' This is an oversimplification. While Sunday closures alone do not cause systemic tourism failures, they do contribute to a cumulative erosion of competitiveness — alongside infrastructure gaps, service quality issues, and regulatory unpredictability — that shapes destination perception over time.

The Ministry also notes a labour market paradox: many retail workers in coastal areas during summer are themselves seasonal tourism employees. The seasonal workforce — often young, female, and on fixed-term contracts — may actually prefer Sunday premium pay opportunities during the short earning season. A rigid non-working Sunday eliminates this option without consulting the workers most affected by tourism seasonality.

The social protection rationale is understood and respected. Workers deserve rest, dignity, and predictable schedules. But the instrument chosen — a blanket ban without sectoral or seasonal differentiation — is blunt where precision is needed. EU member states with mature tourism sectors have consistently adopted more nuanced approaches, balancing worker protection with tourism functionality through designated tourist zones, seasonal calendars, rotational rest-day systems, and enhanced Sunday pay premiums.

counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Tourism would have supported the non-working Sunday principle with a simultaneous, built-in seasonal exemption for legally designated tourist zones. Rather than passing a blanket ban and leaving the seasonal modification for undefined future consideration, the law should have been adopted as a single integrated package: non-working Sundays as the national default from November to April, with permitted Sunday operations in designated tourist municipalities from May to October, accompanied by mandatory 50% Sunday pay premiums and guaranteed rotational rest days for affected workers. This approach honours both worker dignity and tourism functionality.

Positions Montenegro as aligning with EU tourism governance best practices ahead of accession negotiations
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. The Croatian tourist zone model is well-established EU precedent, and Montenegro already maintains municipal tourism classification systems through the NTO. The seasonal exemption concept is reportedly already 'under consideration' in parliament — the Ministry's proposal simply accelerates and formalises what is already acknowledged as necessary. The main political obstacle is the symbolic narrative around Sunday rest, but the integrated worker protection measures (premium pay, rotational rest) should satisfy both labour unions and social protection advocates. Legislative drafting could be completed within 4–6 weeks if prioritised, well before the May tourism season.

debate.consensus_summary: All ministries acknowledge that protecting retail workers' right to weekly rest is a legitimate social policy objective grounded in human rights standards and consistent with EU social policy values. There is broad agreement that the absence of a seasonal tourism exemption is a significant oversight that must be urgently addressed before the 2026 summer season. Every ministry that addressed procedural concerns agrees that no regulatory impact assessment was conducted prior to the extraordinary session, which represents a governance deficit. There is also widespread consensus that the Constitutional Court's specific concerns about equal treatment and proportionality may not have been adequately addressed in the new amendments, creating a risk of repeated judicial invalidation.
disagreements: Economic impact severity: The Ministry of Finance estimates €10-15 million in annual VAT revenue loss; the Ministry of Economy projects €30-60 million in lost retail turnover. The Ministries of Health and Education view these costs as acceptable trade-offs for worker wellbeing and family cohesion, while Finance, Economy, and Tourism consider them disproportionate without compensatory measures.

Rule of law and constitutional legitimacy: The Ministry of Justice and Ministry of EU Integration view the extraordinary session as a dangerous precedent of legislative override of judicial review, threatening Chapter 23 benchmarks and judicial independence. The Ministries of Health and Education implicitly treat the parliamentary action as a legitimate exercise of legislative sovereignty in pursuit of social protection goals.

Tourism competitiveness versus worker protection: The Ministry of Tourism warns of material harm to cruise tourism in Kotor, competitive disadvantage against Croatia and Albania, and lost revenue in coastal municipalities. The Ministry of Health counters that any tourism exemption must include binding health safeguards — maximum consecutive working Sundays, compensatory rest, and weekly hour caps — to prevent erosion of the health protections the law intends.

Approach to Sunday work: The Ministry of Economy and Ministry of Finance advocate for alternatives such as voluntary Sunday opening with enhanced premium pay (150% of wages) and stronger labor inspectorate enforcement, rather than outright prohibition. The Ministries of Health and Education favor the mandatory rest day as a baseline social protection, with the Ministry of Health noting that voluntary arrangements often fail to protect workers with weaker bargaining positions.

EU accession signaling: The Ministry of EU Integration sees the decision as a net negative for Montenegro's accession narrative, likely to be flagged as a rule-of-law concern in the next Country Report. The Ministry of Education argues the decision could be positively framed as alignment with the European Pillar of Social Rights. The Ministry of Justice warns the manner of adoption will be more scrutinized than the substance.

SME and micro-enterprise impact: The Ministry of Economy argues for size-based differentiation, exempting micro-enterprises (fewer than 10 employees) that depend on weekend revenue for viability. No other ministry explicitly addresses this concern, and the Health and Education ministries focus on the benefits to workers regardless of employer size.

Grey economy risks: The Ministry of Interior warns that mandatory Sunday closure may drive informal and unregistered retail activity, particularly in tourist zones and border areas, potentially exploitable by organized crime. Other ministries do not address this enforcement dimension.

## PARLIAMENTARY DEBATE TRANSCRIPT
### Extraordinary Session — Skupština Crne Gore
### Subject: Reinstatement of Non-Working Sunday for Retail Workers
### Date: 16 February 2026

---

### I. OPENING: FRAMING THE DECISION

The Parliament convened in extraordinary session to debate and vote on amendments to the Law on Internal Trade reinstating Sunday as a non-working day for retail employees. The measure was introduced following the Constitutional Court's recent invalidation of the original provision on grounds of unequal treatment and disproportionate restriction on entrepreneurial freedom. All 62 deputies present voted in favor. The following synthesis presents the positions of all relevant ministries, identifies areas of consensus and contention, and weighs the arguments in light of Montenegro's national interest.

---

### II. POSITIONS OF THE MINISTRIES

#### A. Ministries Supporting the Decision (Positive Assessments)

**Ministry of Health (Score: 7/10 — Positive):**
The Ministry of Health presents the strongest case in favor. It argues that guaranteed weekly rest is a well-established determinant of physical and mental health, directly benefiting the estimated 15,000–20,000 retail workers in Montenegro — a workforce disproportionately composed of women. The Ministry frames the decision as aligned with the EU Working Time Directive and the European Pillar of Social Rights. It emphasizes that voluntary arrangements for Sunday work often fail to protect workers with weak bargaining positions, making mandatory rest the more effective instrument. However, the Ministry conditions its support on three caveats: (1) pharmacy access on Sundays must not be disrupted, particularly in underserved municipalities like Pljevlja and Bijelo Polje; (2) any tourism-season exemption must include binding health safeguards — a maximum of four consecutive working Sundays, mandatory compensatory rest within 14 days, and a 48-hour weekly cap; and (3) the decision should be accompanied by occupational health monitoring for retail workers, which is currently absent.

**Ministry of Education (Score: 7/10 — Positive):**
The Ministry of Education highlights meaningful indirect benefits: improved family cohesion for parents of school-age children, better conditions for student-workers in retail, and a guaranteed day for educational and cultural participation. It notes that many retail workers are VET graduates or part-time university students whose academic performance suffers from irregular schedules. The Ministry proposes a 'Sunday Learning' initiative offering free educational programming on the newly guaranteed rest day. It cautions, however, that the decision was taken without consulting the Ministry of Education, the University of Montenegro, or student unions, and that tourism-season exemptions must safeguard VET dual-education students in hospitality placements.

#### B. Ministries Opposing the Decision (Negative Assessments)

**Ministry of Justice (Score: 3/10 — Negative):**
The Ministry of Justice delivers the most severe critique. It characterizes the extraordinary session as a direct legislative override of the Constitutional Court, undertaken without demonstrably addressing the constitutional deficiencies the Court identified. The Ministry warns that this sets a dangerous precedent: if Parliament can simply re-enact provisions struck down by the Court through extraordinary sessions, the binding nature of constitutional adjudication is effectively nullified. The immediate entry into force without adequate vacatio legis violates the principle of legal certainty. The Ministry recommends seeking a Venice Commission opinion on the compatibility of this legislative practice with European standards on constitutional adjudication and judicial independence. It predicts with high confidence that the provision will face a new constitutional challenge, potentially triggering an adversarial cycle between Parliament and the Court that damages Montenegro's rule-of-law credentials.

**Ministry of EU Integration (Score: 4/10 — Negative):**
The Ministry of EU Integration reinforces the Justice Ministry's rule-of-law concerns through the specific lens of EU accession. It warns that the European Commission's next Country Report will almost certainly reference this episode as a rule-of-law concern under Chapters 23 and 24. The unanimity and speed of the legislative response creates an appearance of Parliament subordinating constitutional review to political consensus, undermining the separation of powers — a core Copenhagen criterion. The Ministry notes that claims made during debate that Sunday closures would reduce inflation are economically unfounded and may raise concerns about evidence-based policymaking. It recommends proactive engagement with DG NEAR to frame the decision within EU social policy values, but acknowledges this will be difficult given the procedural deficiencies.

**Ministry of Economy (Score: 3/10 — Negative):**
The Ministry of Economy presents the most comprehensive economic case against the decision. It estimates annual retail turnover losses of €30–60 million, disproportionately affecting coastal and urban municipalities. It argues that the blanket prohibition fails to differentiate between large retail chains and micro-enterprises (fewer than 10 employees) — family businesses most dependent on weekend revenue. The Ministry challenges the inflation argument directly, noting that supply restrictions tend to increase, not decrease, consumer prices. It highlights competitive disadvantage against Croatia, Albania, and Greece, where Sunday retail operates in tourist zones. The Ministry advocates for an alternative model: voluntary Sunday opening with mandatory premium pay of at least 150%, strengthened Labor Inspectorate enforcement, and differentiation by enterprise size.

**Ministry of Finance (Score: 4/10 — Negative):**
The Ministry of Finance quantifies the fiscal damage: an estimated €10–15 million annual reduction in VAT revenue, with no compensatory fiscal measures identified. It emphasizes that no fiscal impact assessment was conducted before the extraordinary session, violating governance standards under the Law on Budget and Fiscal Responsibility. The Ministry warns of negative signals to foreign direct investment, particularly international retail chains evaluating market entry. It proposes a mandatory annual review mechanism requiring joint Finance-Economy reporting to Parliament on the law's fiscal effects, and urges immediate legislation of a tourist-season exemption (June 1 – September 30) to protect coastal municipal revenues.

**Ministry of Tourism (Score: 4/10 — Negative):**
The Ministry of Tourism warns of material harm to Montenegro's tourism competitiveness. It highlights the specific vulnerability of Kotor, where cruise ship passengers arriving on Sundays will encounter closed retail establishments — risking cruise line itinerary changes away from Montenegro. The Ministry notes that tour operators and cruise lines programme destinations 6–12 months in advance, and abrupt regulatory changes undermine Montenegro's reliability as a partner destination. It recommends fast-tracking a seasonal exemption before May 2026, adopting the Croatian model of differentiating by store size (allowing shops under 200 square metres in tourist zones to operate on Sundays year-round), and implementing a rotational rest-day system rather than a blanket Sunday prohibition.

#### C. Neutral Positions

**Ministry of Environment (Score: 5/10 — Neutral):**
The Ministry of Environment identifies modest indirect environmental co-benefits from reduced Sunday commercial activity — lower energy consumption, reduced transport emissions, and decreased waste generation — but cautions that compressed shopping into six days may partially offset these gains through intensified Saturday peaks. It raises a specific concern about potential tourist-season exemptions increasing environmental pressure in coastal municipalities and near national parks. The Ministry recommends mandatory environmental safeguards for any exemption zones, including enhanced waste collection and air quality monitoring near Natura 2000 candidate sites.

**Ministry of Interior (Score: 5/10 — Neutral):**
The Ministry of Interior views the decision as primarily a labour and trade policy matter with limited impact on its core mandate. It notes modest benefits (reduced Sunday policing burden in commercial zones) and modest risks (potential grey-economy activity on Sundays). The Ministry's most significant concern is the lack of a clear inter-institutional coordination protocol between the Market Inspection Directorate and the police for enforcement, and it warns that contemplated tourism exceptions with unclear parameters could generate enforcement confusion and divert limited police resources.

---

### III. CROSS-CUTTING ANALYSIS

#### A. The Constitutional and Rule-of-Law Question
The most consequential disagreement is not about the merits of Sunday rest but about the constitutional legitimacy of the process. The Ministries of Justice and EU Integration form a strong bloc arguing that the extraordinary session format effectively circumvents the Constitutional Court — a position that carries weight given Montenegro's EU accession trajectory. The Ministries of Health and Education do not directly counter this argument but implicitly treat the parliamentary action as a legitimate exercise of legislative authority. The opposition perspective, which would likely echo the Justice and EU Integration concerns, is notably absent from the debate record despite the decision's unanimity. Civil society organizations focused on rule of law — such as the Centre for Civic Education and MANS — would likely raise similar constitutional concerns.

#### B. The Tourism Emergency
All ministries that address tourism agree that a seasonal exemption is urgently needed before the 2026 summer season. The gap between acknowledging this need and having no legislative mechanism in place represents the decision's most immediate practical vulnerability. The Ministry of Tourism's warning about cruise line itinerary decisions — made 6–12 months in advance — suggests that damage to the 2026 season may already be difficult to prevent.

#### C. The Missing Impact Assessment
Seven of eight ministries either explicitly note or implicitly acknowledge the absence of a regulatory impact assessment. This is not merely a procedural criticism — it means Parliament voted unanimously on a measure whose economic, social, and legal effects were not quantified. The Ministry of Finance's call for a retrospective fiscal impact assessment within 60 days reflects a consensus that evidence must now be generated after the fact.

#### D. Worker Protection vs. Worker Choice
A deeper philosophical tension underlies the debate: does protecting workers require prohibiting Sunday work, or would enhanced protections for those who choose to work (premium pay, voluntary scheduling, compensatory rest) better serve worker interests? The Ministries of Economy and Finance advocate the latter; the Ministry of Health argues that voluntary arrangements are illusory in sectors with power imbalances. This remains unresolved.

---

### IV. WEIGHING THE ARGUMENTS IN THE NATIONAL INTEREST

Montenegro's national interest requires balancing four priorities: (1) genuine worker protection; (2) economic competitiveness, particularly in tourism; (3) rule-of-law credibility for EU accession; and (4) constitutional order.

On worker protection, the case is strong — the Ministries of Health and Education present compelling evidence that mandatory rest serves a vulnerable, predominantly female workforce.

On economic competitiveness, the case against the blanket ban is also strong — the Ministries of Economy, Finance, and Tourism present credible evidence of fiscal, tourism, and SME harm that was not assessed before the vote.

On rule of law and constitutional order, the concerns raised by the Ministries of Justice and EU Integration are the most serious. Montenegro's EU accession path — its declared strategic priority — depends on demonstrating respect for judicial independence and constitutional review. The perception that Parliament overrode the Constitutional Court through an extraordinary session, regardless of the merits of the underlying policy, risks tangible consequences in the next EU Progress Report.

The balance of arguments suggests that while the policy objective is sound, the execution was deficient in three critical respects: (1) the process undermined constitutional order; (2) the economic impact was not assessed; and (3) the urgent need for a tourism-season exemption was acknowledged but not addressed.

---

### V. VERDICT

The overall assessment is **NEGATIVE** — not because worker rest protections are undesirable, but because the decision as adopted suffers from procedural deficits that threaten its constitutional sustainability, economic consequences that were neither quantified nor mitigated, and a gap between the acknowledged need for tourism flexibility and the absence of any mechanism to deliver it. A properly designed Sunday rest regime — with a robust regulatory impact assessment, adequate vacatio legis, proportionate exemptions for tourism zones and micro-enterprises, enhanced premium pay provisions, and demonstrable engagement with the Constitutional Court's specific concerns — would likely have earned a positive assessment. The decision as adopted does not meet that standard.

blind_spots: No polling data or worker surveys cited — the 'worker protection' framing assumes workers universally want Sundays off, but many low-wage retail workers, particularly seasonal and part-time workers, actively seek Sunday premium pay to make ends meet. Nobody asked them.

The religious dimension is entirely unaddressed. Sunday — not Saturday, not a rotating day — was chosen as the mandated rest day. In a secular state with Muslim, Orthodox, and Catholic populations observing different holy days, the exclusive privileging of Sunday carries an implicit cultural-religious bias that no ministry flagged.

Consumer impact is barely mentioned. Montenegrin citizens — not just tourists — also shop on Sundays. Single parents, shift workers in other sectors, and people in rural areas with limited transport options lose a shopping day. No ministry centered the ordinary citizen-consumer perspective.

The enforcement gap in Montenegro's labour inspectorate is ignored. If the existing Labour Inspectorate cannot enforce current labour laws (overtime limits, minimum wage compliance, occupational safety), adding another prohibition to enforce is performative legislation.

No ministry examined whether the 'amendment' actually cures the Constitutional Court's objections. The equal treatment problem — some businesses open, others closed — appears to persist if bakeries, gas stations, pharmacies, and hospitality are exempt. This is the exact deficiency the Court identified.

The political economy is unexamined: PES called this extraordinary session. Why? The cynical but obvious reading is that this is a populist move to shore up voter support among a large retail workforce ahead of potential elections. No ministry acknowledged this dimension.

Impact on e-commerce and digital economy ignored. Sunday closures in physical retail accelerate the shift to online shopping, which often means purchases from foreign platforms (Amazon, Temu, AliExpress), draining spending out of the Montenegrin economy entirely and generating zero local VAT.

No analysis of the actual text of the amendments versus the struck-down provision. Every ministry discusses the decision in the abstract without examining whether the new legal text substantively differs from what the Constitutional Court invalidated.
critic_report.overall_analysis:
This decision is a textbook case of populist legislating that wraps a constitutionally dubious act in the appealing language of worker protection. Let me be blunt about what happened: Montenegro's Constitutional Court — the institution charged with upholding the constitution — ruled that a Sunday trading ban was unconstitutional because it discriminated between business types. Parliament's response was not to carefully redesign the law to address the Court's concerns. Instead, the ruling party convened an extraordinary session and rammed through what appears to be substantially the same prohibition, with 62-0 unanimity that suggests political choreography rather than genuine deliberation.

This is institutional vandalism dressed up as social policy.

The substance vs. the process must be separated. On substance, there is a legitimate case for protecting retail workers' rest. The EU Working Time Directive guarantees weekly rest. Many EU states restrict Sunday trading. Workers — especially women bearing double domestic burdens — deserve dignity and predictability. Score: reasonable policy goal. But the instrument is crude. A blanket Sunday ban, rather than mandatory premium pay, rotational rest days, or strengthened labour inspection, is the laziest possible policy tool. It doesn't actually help workers who will simply be forced to work longer hours Monday through Saturday. It doesn't touch the 25-35% informal economy where labour protections don't exist on paper or in practice.

On process, this is alarming. The Constitutional Court exists to check legislative power. When Parliament responds to a constitutional ruling by immediately re-enacting the invalidated provision in an extraordinary session, it sends one message: we don't respect judicial review. The Venice Commission has flagged exactly this pattern in Hungary, Poland, and Serbia as corrosive to democratic governance. Montenegro — which has staked its future on EU accession and which is under Chapter 23 scrutiny precisely on judicial independence — cannot afford this. The European Commission will notice. Credit rating agencies will notice. Foreign investors will notice.

The Ministry of Justice (score: 3/10) and Ministry of EU Integration (score: 4/10) deserve credit for flagging the rule-of-law crisis this represents. Their analyses are the strongest and most honest. The Ministry of Finance (score: 4/10) raises legitimate fiscal concerns, though its €10-15 million VAT loss estimate feels speculative without a proper RIA. The Ministry of Tourism (score: 4/10) correctly identifies the competitive and cruise-ship implications.

Conversely, the Ministry of Health (score: 7/10) and Ministry of Education (score: 7/10) offer well-meaning but somewhat credulous assessments that treat the stated social policy rationale at face value without adequately questioning whether this specific instrument achieves the stated goals. The Ministry of Environment and Interior assessments are competent but peripheral — correctly identifying their limited relevance.

The single most damning fact: no regulatory impact assessment was conducted. No fiscal impact assessment. No public consultation. No worker survey. This law was passed in an extraordinary session — a procedure meant for emergencies — to address a policy disagreement with a court. That is not how democracies legislate.

The tourism exemption gap is immediately dangerous. The law takes effect upon gazette publication, meaning the entire 2026 summer season — Montenegro's economic lifeline — will operate under a Sunday closure regime with no exemption for Kotor's cruise passengers, Budva's beach tourists, or Žabljak's hikers. The promised 'modified version' for tourist season is vapourware — not drafted, not scheduled, not guaranteed.

What should have happened: Parliament should have taken 60-90 days to draft a constitutionally sound law that (a) addresses the Court's equal treatment concerns with a coherent exemption framework, (b) includes a seasonal/geographic flexibility mechanism for tourism, (c) mandates Sunday premium pay as an alternative to prohibition, (d) is accompanied by a proper RIA and fiscal impact assessment, and (e) includes a reasonable vacatio legis period. Instead, it chose political spectacle over governance.

Final verdict: The decision scores a 4/10 — not because protecting workers is wrong, but because this specific law is likely unconstitutional again, was adopted through a process that damages Montenegro's rule-of-law credentials, includes no seasonal exemption that the economy desperately needs, and was passed without basic impact assessment. The ministries collectively score 7/10 — the Justice and EU Integration assessments are genuinely strong, Finance and Tourism are competent, and Health/Education are decent if somewhat uncritical. The major blind spot across all ministries is the failure to examine whether the amended text actually fixes the constitutional defect, and the complete absence of the citizen-consumer and informal-economy perspectives.
